The Kharidian–Zarosian War was a series of major battles in the northern Kharidian Lands in the Second Age. Zaros had been expanding his empire which shared a border with the Kharidian lands, which were ruled over by a group of gods called the Menaphite Pantheon.

The war started from simple border skirmishes, that broke out due to the Menaphites fear of the expanding Zarosian Empire, whom the Menaphites named the "Ruinous Powers".[1] To hold back the Zarosian forces, the gods of the Menaphite Pantheon granted their people powerful weapons.[2] Despite this, the Zarosians remained on the winning side, quickly conquering the Menaphite's terrain.

Icthlarin, the Menaphite god of the dead, left Gielinor to seek powerful allies, and eventually arrived to the war-ridden plane of Freneskae. There, he convinced many members of the extremely powerful race of Mahjarrat to swear allegiance to him and vanquish the Zarosian armies. He then took the Mahjarrat with him to Gielinor, whom the Menaphites named as Icthlarin's Stern Judges.[3]

Over the next few years with the Mahjarrat's aid, Icthlarin was able to gradually drive back the Zarosian forces out of the Kharidian Lands.[4] However, once Osmumten became the Pharaoh, the Mahjarrat defected to the Zarosian Empire as a result of Sliske, who'd convinced them to abandon Icthlarin.[5]

The Zarosian forces, now with the Mahjarrat added to their ranks, once again pushed the Menaphites back.[6] In a desperate last stand, the god Tumeken sacrificed himself using a magical blast of fire, causing the total annihilation of the armies on both sides and devastation the surrounding area, resulting in the once lush lands becoming a desert.[7]

Osmumten, despite having led the Kharidians with the support of the Menaphite Pantheon, was largely blamed for the result the war had wrought on his people, and was killed with the rest of his family,[8] save his son Mehhar, who'd gone into hiding in Ullek. Prior to his death, Osmumten was tasked with hiding the powerful weapons the Menaphite Pantheon had granted them; two of these were buried with him in the Jaltevas Pyramid,[9] which are said to be able to transfer a god's divinity to another, allowing the receiver to ascend to godhood.[10]

References[edit | edit source]

  1. ^ Mehhar, "Beneath Cursed Sands", Old School RuneScape. "During the great war, our forces were decimated by the servants of the Ruinous Powers."
  2. ^ Mehhar, "Beneath Cursed Sands", Old School RuneScape. "At the time of his [Osmumten's] rule, our people were locked in a great war. To hold back the Ruinous Powers, our gods granted us immensely powerful weapons."
  3. ^ Mehhar, "Beneath Cursed Sands", Old School RuneScape. "To turn the tide, Icthlarin and Amascut sought powerful allies to aid us. They found them far from here, in a place beyond this world. A powerful race of faceless ones. They became Icthlarin's Stern Judges."
  4. ^ Mehhar, "Beneath Cursed Sands", Old School RuneScape. "The armies of the Ruinous Powers were far stronger than our own. That was until Icthlarin's Stern Judges joined the fray. Thanks to them, the war was seemingly won."
  5. ^ Mehhar, "Beneath Cursed Sands", Old School RuneScape. "Among the Stern Judges, there was a serpent. After my father [Osmumten] became Pharaoh, this serpent convinced the others to abandon us."
  6. ^ Mehhar, "Beneath Cursed Sands", Old School RuneScape. "We were powerless against a force of that might. Nothing could stop their advance."
  7. ^ Mehhar, "Beneath Cursed Sands", Old School RuneScape. "[So how did the war end?] It was Tumeken himself. He sacrificed himself to annihilate the enemy. The cost was great, but the war was won."
  8. ^ Mehhar, "Beneath Cursed Sands", Old School RuneScape. "My father ruled during the great war. While the war was eventually won, many considered the cost too great. My father led us with the support of the gods, yet he was the one people blamed. [So they killed him?] Him, and the rest of my family."
  9. ^ Mehhar, "Beneath Cursed Sands", Old School RuneScape. "When the war was over, my father was tasked with hiding those weapons, lest they fall into nefarious hands. Two of them were buried with him."
  10. ^ Mehhar, "Beneath Cursed Sands", Old School RuneScape. "The weapons in my father's tomb can be used to drain a being of divine energy and transfer that energy to another. If used correctly, they would grant the Devourer true godhood."
